awd_titl_txt: RII Track-2 FEC: The Creation of Next-Generation Tools for Neuroscience - Noninvasive Radioluminescence Approaches to Optogenetics
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description
This Research Infrastructure Improvement Track-2 Focused EPSCoR Collaboration (RII Track-2 FEC) proposal is a collaboration between four institutions in South Carolina, Alabama, and New Mexico, namely Clemson University, the University of Alabama Birmingham, the University of New Mexico, and the University of South Carolina. The aim of the project is to extend the uses of the experimental method of optogenetics, which, since its introduction in 2005, has had a transformative impact on neurobiology. This method allows experimenters to activate individual neurons or groups of neurons, with high levels of spatial and temporal control, by flashing light on them. One of the main limitations of standard optogenetics is the inability of visible light to penetrate deep within living tissues. In this project, a system will be developed to allow the use of low-dosage X-rays, rather than visible light, as the activating signal. The project includes multiple opportunities to involve students, especially members of under-represented minority groups. Agreements are in place to host students from Winthrop University and Northern New Mexico College, which serve highly diverse student populations, in existing summer research programs at the research-intensive universities. The project also includes plans for mentoring junior faculty, especially in proposal development.

Technical Description
This multi-disciplinary project involves step-wise development of novel experimental methods. First, radioluminescent nanoparticles (RLPs) will be produced that emit light when exposed to X-rays. The RLPs will be chemically modified to allow specific covalent attachment to a genetically engineered membrane-bound opsin protein expressed in neurons, ensuring close proximity of the two components for efficient transfer of the light stimulus. The system will be tested (for efficacy and the absence of undesired side effects) in cultured cells, then brain slice preparations, and finally in intact animals (rats and mice). RLPs will be introduced into animals by injection into the cerebrospinal fluid, through which the particles may diffuse into the brain. The effects of X-ray exposure on the behavior of immobilized and freely moving animals will then be tested to verify successful activation of neural cells in the motor and auditory cortexes.

por.por_cntn:
Overall, the accomplishments completed at Clemson University (CU), the University of Alabama (UAB), the University of New Mexico (UNM), and the University of South Carolina (USC) throughout the course of the award have met the proposed goals. Several published works have been produced and published in high-impact journals. Since 2016, thirty-six peer-reviewed publications have resulted from this award and have been deposited into the NSF Public Access Repository. Of these thirty-six publications, one is a collaborative paper from CU, UAB, and UNM, five are collaborative papers from CU and UAB, one is a collaborative paper from CU and UNM, and two are collaborative papers from CU and USC. Individually, CU published sixteen papers, UAB published five papers, UNM published five papers, and USC published one paper. Additionally, the activities at CU, UAB, UNM, and USC have been presented to a variety of audiences throughout the award in order to enhance scientific and technological understanding. A total of one hundred sixteen, sixty-five, forty-one, and twelve talks and posters based on this award have been presented by CU, UAB, UNM, and USC, respectively. Furthermore, thirty-eight proposals have been submitted by all four universities, which has resulted in two awarded to CU, eight awarded to UAB, and four awarded to UNM, and two awarded to USC. 

 

Teaching, training, and learning while advancing discovery was continuously promoted by CU, UAB, and UNM by training new graduate students and involving new undergraduate student in research experiences. Throughout the award, a total of twenty-two graduate students have been supported: twelve at CU, six at UAB, and four at UNM. Of these students, one masters (MS) and thirteen doctorate (PhD) degrees have been awarded. Additionally, undergraduates were mentored and trained to do various research activities throughout the award, including four undergraduates at UAB and eighteen undergraduates at CU. Furthermore, four postdoctoral research associates have been mentored according to a Postdoctoral Researcher Mentoring Plan prepared at their respective universities as a part of this award. 

 

Regarding broader impact, a total of sixty-two undergraduate students have participated in a summer research program at CU. The primary goal of the summer research program was to broaden the participation of historically underrepresented groups (HUGS) in the field of materials science and engineering and encourage HUGS to apply to STEM graduate programs. Through a ten-week program in a laboratory setting, undergraduate students from HUGS were provided with the tools and skills essential for a future in materials science and engineering. In Years 1-3, a total of twenty-eight undergraduate students participated in the Charles H. Townes Optical Science and Engineering Summer Program. In Years 4-6, a total of thirty-four undergraduate students participated in the Center of Optical Materials Science and Engineering Technologies' (COMSET's) Advanced Materials Summer Research Program.

 

Regarding intellectual merit, a new route to synthesizing cerium-, europium-, and terbium-doped yttrium/lutetium orthosilicate radioluminescent particles (RLPs) involving a carbon sacrificial layer separation method was developed and optimized at CU. This new sacrificial method was a major milestone that allowed for an increased yield of un-aggregated nanoparticles and greater control over phase conversion and nanoparticle morphology. Extending on the blue-, green-, and red-emitting mono-doped RLPs synthesized using the new sacrificial approach, the radioluminescence output was enhanced by co-doping the RLPs and "click" chemistry could be employed to coat the nanoparticles in bovine serum albumin (BSA) for increased biocompatibility. Additionally, synthetic procedures for other inorganic RLPs that are not orthosilicate phases and blue-, green-, and red-emitting organic RLPs were established.  At UAB major milestones have been achieved throughout the award, including good biocompatibility found between RLPs and neuronal cultures and acutely prepared brain slices, successful delivery of RLPs and AAV9-hsyn-GFP virus to the hippocampus of a rodent model utilizing focused ultrasounds (FUS) to non-invasively open the blood brain barrier (BBB), and investigations of an alternative photoreceptor protein, LITE-1, found in C. elegan nematodes for optogenetics.  At UNM major milestones have been achieved throughout the award including, the production of a deliverable good (SNAP-Halo-GFP) that can be distributed to the scientific community and used for a host of purposes and a proof of principle study in collaboration with CU and UAB demonstrating the ability of RLPs to increase cAMP production through a light-gated receptor in vitro. Lastly, major milestones accomplished at USC throughout the award include the development and optimization of a salt-supported high temperature reaction mechanism to produce scintillating, cerium-doped lutecium pyrosilicate nanoparticles. Additionally, methods to synthesize rare earth doped potassium gadolinium fluoride particles with an added passivation layer to increase light output have been established. One important change that occurred in Year 3 was the use of additional opsins to amplify RLP-induced signals via biological cascades. Additionally, it is important to note that the COVID-19 pandemic significantly impacted and delayed the flow of work at CU, UAB, UNM, and USC in Years 4-6.
